intro: Parahancornia peruviana, commonly known as the Peruvian milkweed, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 3 meters tall, featuring woody stems and thick, fleshy leaves. The plant produces yellow-orange flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom during the dry season. Its latex sap is milky and can be toxic, a characteristic shared with other members of the Apocynaceae family. The plant is adapted to arid environments and is often found in rocky soils at higher elevations.
